ARABIC: خَلَقَ ٱلْإِنسَٰنَ مِن نُّطْفَةٍ فَإِذَا هُوَ خَصِيمٌ مُّبِينٌ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: He created man from a drop of sperm and yet he is an open challenger!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Man He created from a drop of semen; and still he becomes an open contender.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: He created man out of a mere drop of fluid, and lo! he turned into an open wrangler.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: He created the human being from a drop of fluid but the human being openly disputes His Word.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: He created man from a drop of fluid, yet he is an open quarreller!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: He has created man from a Nutfah, then behold, this same (man) becomes an open opponent.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: He created man from a small seed and lo! he is an open contender.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: He created man of a sperm-drop; and, behold, he is a manifest adversary.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: He hath created man from a drop of fluid, yet behold! he is an open opponent.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: He created man out of a [mere] drop of sperm: yet he shows himself to be openly contentious!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: He hath created man from a drop, and Lo! he is a disputer open.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: He created man from a drop of [seminal] fluid, and, behold, he is an open contender!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: He has created man from a sperm-drop; and behold this same (man) becomes an open disputer!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: He has created man from Nutfah (mixed drops of male and female sexual discharge), then behold, this same (man) becomes an open opponent.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: He created mankind from a sperm drop, yet he is a clear adversary.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: He created the human being from a drop of fluid, yet he becomes an open adversary.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: He created man from a sperm-drop; then at once, he is a clear adversary.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [16:4] He created man from a drop of fluid, of sperm, until He makes him strong and tough, yet behold! he is disputatious, extremely quarrelsome, openly, making this [disputatiousness] clear in his rejection of resurrection, contending: Who shall revive the bones when they are decayed? [Q. 36:78].
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (He hath created man) the reference here is to Ubayy Ibn Khalaf al-Jumahi (from a drop of) stinking (fluid, yet behold! he is an open opponent) openly arguing in favour of falsehood, saying: Who will revive these bones when they rot away?
